gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Geography Department, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Landcover Bcn-Girona 12 categories (Landcover Classification of a Landsat scene)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Probabilistic landcover digital maps and classification quality indicators. Maps have been generated by means of remote sensing corrections, statistical techniques, hybrid classification processing, probabilistic models by logistic and linear regression, Geographic Information Systems analysis and methods comparison -sensitivity testing-.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Classification products derived from remote sensing scenes are widely used. However, the accuracy indicators provided at pixel and object level are not always available. Probability of belonging to the assigned class should be quantified and communicated to the user. In addition to the standard classification product of a crisp classification, several quality indicators derived from the classifier parameters and uncertainty statistical models, togther with the probability for every class is provided at pixel level and object level. Coherence between the common global indicators extracted from the confusion matrix and the pixel or object indicators is assessed in this multilayer product. Finally, the comparison of results between different classifiers is intended to cover sensitivity testing performance. A relevant characteristic for the creation of this product is the usage as ground truth of a detailed landcover map obtained by photointerpretation matching the temporal series of the scenes, covering around 41.38% of the whole area of study.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Geography Department, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona
Geography Department, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: The product is intended to provide insights on error modelling and validation. No update is envisaged. Nonetheless, the methodology work flow can be generally applied to classification processes and landcover mapping to obtain per pixel uncertainty estimates, object level and global quality indicators. Temporal comparison of land use can be derived as new RS and ground truth data becomes available.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: There is no use or access limitation.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Per pixel uncertainty modelling and its spatial representation on land cover maps obtained by hybrid classification

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Animal and Plant Biology and Ecology Department, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Remote sensing classification uncertainty: validating probabilistic pixel level classification

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: Probability for the assigned class (hybrid classifier) obtained from logistic regression model
Second most probable landcover classes (12 categories)
Third most probable landcover classes (12 categories)
Fidelity of the assigned class (12 categories; hybrid classifier)
Fidelity of the second most probable class (12 categories; hybrid classifier)
Fidelity of the third most probable class (12 categories; hybrid classifier)

Promiscuity: introduced concept (in opposition to fidelity) number of thematic categories that could be assigned to a statistic cluster in a hybrid classification consisting on two steps: unsupervised classification/introduction of training areas

Majority categories: introduced concept in the study, related to fidelity and promiscuity. It states the number of categories with a fidelity higher than a determined threshold (in our case 15%) for each statistical class in a hybrid classification consisting on two steps: unsupervised classification/introduction of training areas

Representativity: this expresses the association degree of a statistical class to a thematic class. It is a classifier parameter. It must be interpreted from the inverse point of view as the other variables. Which part of the assigned thematic class a statistical class represents

Representativity of the second most probable class: this expresses the association degree of a statistical class to the second most probable thematic class. It must be interpreted from the inverse point of view as the other variables. Which part of the not assigned thematic class (but the second most probable) a statistical class represents

Representativity of the third most probable class: this expresses the association degree of a statistical class to the third most probable thematic class. It must be interpreted from the inverse point of view as the other variables. Which part of the not assigned thematic class (but the third most probable) a statistical class represents

Probability of success in the thematic class assignment at the object level (object being the statistical cluster in the unsupervised classification stage Isodata product; average probability of success for the number of pixels contained withing the vector layer corresponding to statistical cluster in the unsupervised classification stage Isodata product)

gmx:fileDescription.gco:CharacterString: MMZ encoding of classification data including uncertainty information at pixel level and object level

gmd19157:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Validation of the classification using independent test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC, MCSC_test_12cat source)

gmd19157:samplingScheme.gco:CharacterString: Random sampling with stratification into three lots (all categories included in each of the three lots) (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:lotDescription.gco:CharacterString: Split ground truth buffered-MCSC (MCSC_reclass_buffer) into training subsample (50%, MCSC_train_12cat), test (25%, MCSC_test_12cat) and validation (25%, MCSC_test_test_12cat) subsamples using random stratified sampling methods in R software (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:samplingRatio.gco:CharacterString: 100% of the test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is inspected

gmd19157:valueType.gco:RecordType: Confusion matrix recording counts from ground truthing

un:ConfusionMatrix.un:sourceCategories: Coniferous Esclerophyllous Chestnut Beech OtherDeciduous Shrub Meadows RiceFields Vineyard FruitTreesOrOtherHerbCrops BareOrUrbanSoil Water
un:ConfusionMatrix.un:targetCategories: NODATA Coniferous Esclerophyllous Chestnut Beech OtherDeciduous Shrub Meadows RiceFields Vineyard FruitTreesOrOtherHerbCrops BareOrUrbanSoil Water

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Reclassification of 233 categories (photointerpretation enables a very detailed legend) of the original MCSC into 12 categories. The choice of the classification legend is based on a simplification of MCSC product to a ground truth of 12 categories (using spectral features and biological consistency of the legend categories as main criteria)

gmd19157:rationale.gco:CharacterString: It is a challenge adapting the 233 classes original legend to a subjective choice of 12 categories as it is difficult to adapt a legend obtained by photointerpretation of 0.5 m resolution ortophotos to a remote sensing spatial resolution and spectral features of the land cover. This point is crucial in the global accuracy and limitations of the databases we are using in the whole study. The matching of a biologically consistent land cover classes, the spectral features and RS properties of the landsat scenes, and the photointerpreted MCSC is not easy.

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Land Cover Map of Catalonia MCSC (3rd Edition, raster format) (Mapa de Cobertes del sòl de Catalunya. 3ª Edició, model ràster) (2005-2007). Obtained from photointerpretation of 0.5 m spatial resolution ortophotographies. 233 land cover categories legend. 20m pixel size. Centre de Recerca Ecològica i Aplicacions Forestals CREAF (2007)

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Land Cover Map of Catalonia MCSC (3rd Edition, raster format)

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: CREAF. Edifici C. Campus de Bellaterra (UAB). 08193 Cerdanyola del Vallès. Barcelona. Espanya

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Original MCSC (raster format) reclassified into 12 categories

Obtain a MCSC reclassified raster file with NODATA on the border pixels between categories. The aim of this step is to assure homogeneous training areas and avoid introducing the mixtures that characterize the transition between landcover categories.
MCSC reclassified raster file with NODATA on the border pixels (result of the Buffer_MCSC_reclass process step)
Vectorize the MCSC reclassified raster file
MSCS vector (result of the Vectorize_MCSC_reclass process step)

Combination of the vectorized MCSC with a 1km grid. This partition is applied to fragment larger polygons into several smaller polygons, with the aim of selecting a % of its surface for posterior sampling purposes (training areas, test areas, validation areas subsamples). Thus, only the larger polygons are fragmentated.
Combination of the vectorized MCSC with a 1km grid

Finally, a stratified subsampling using a R syntax randomly assigns each gridded MCSC polygon (MCSC_vector_grid source) values 1 to 3. Value 1 are training polygons (50% of the area), value 2 are test polygons (25% of the area) and value 3 are validation polygons (25% of the area). Accordingly, this layer is split into three polygon layers. One of each is combined with the MCSC reclassified raster file with NODATA on the border pixels (MCSC_reclass_buffer source) to generate three raster files with (training pixels, test pixels and validation pixels, with sources id's equal to MCSC_train_12cat, MCSC_test_12cat, MCSC_test_test_12cat). Each of these raster subsamples contain all the categories included on the legend (12 categories).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Test test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC)

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: See more details about the generation of this layer in MCSC_test_12cat source description.

gmd19157:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Spatialization of the classification success probability using independent test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC, MCSC_test_12cat source)

gmd19157:samplingScheme.gco:CharacterString: Random sampling with stratification into three lots (all categories included in each of the three lots) (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:lotDescription.gco:CharacterString: Split ground truth buffered-MCSC (MCSC_reclass_buffer) into training subsample (50%, MCSC_train_12cat), test (25%, MCSC_test_12cat) and validation (25%, MCSC_test_test_12cat) subsamples using random stratified sampling methods in R software (Stratified_random_sampling process step). The test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is used to define the dependent variable in the logistic regression model: success/failure binomial variable setting a 2 values reclassification of the overlaying of the classification product (ClsMix_12cat layer id="LC") and the test ground truth lot (MCSC_test_12cat) i.e., 1=agreement between ClsMix_12cat and MCSCtest, 0=disagreement between ClsMix_12cat and MCSCtest. Note that the overlaying of the classification product (ClsMix_12cat layer) and the test ground truth lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is actually the spatialization of the Confusion Matrix described in the previous quality report.

gmd19157:samplingRatio.gco:CharacterString: 100% of the test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is inspected. However this procedure implies that only 25% of the ground truth area is used in model fitting and then 10% of this 25% is sampled in the statistical model fitting in order to avoid spatial correlation (still 1105303 pixels analysed)

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Reclassification of the IsoMM with the statistical class values obtained in the second step (supervised classification: from the IsoMM unsupervised classification + training areas) in the hybrid classification product fidelity F, second fidelity F2, third fidelity F3, representativity R, second representativity R2, third representativity R3 obtained from the hybrid classification report (ClsMix_12cat report), and computation of entropy H, promiscuity P, uncertainty I and majority classes Q. This way pixel level values for all these variables (independent variables in regression model fitting) are obtained

MCSC test areas are overlaid to the product of the hybrid classification (ClsMix_12cat ID="LC") to check in which pixels the ground truth (MCSC) categories coincide with the categories assigned in the hybrid classification. This is the spatialization of the confusion matrix described in report 1. The resulting layer is reclassified into a binomial layer in which 1=coincidence in category (correct pixel) or 0=non coincidence in category (incorrectly classified pixel). This layer is actually the dependent variable in the logistic regression model fitting step.

MCSC test areas are overlaid to the product of the hybrid classification (ClsMix_12cat ID="LC") to check in which pixels the ground truth (MCSC) categories coincide with the categories assigned in the hybrid classification.

Logistic regression model fitting using SPSS statistical software (subsample of 10% of the dataset).Selection of model depending on goodness of fit statistics (R2 Negelkerke, Cox adjusted R2) and apply the model formula in the algebra calculator module in MiraMon GIS software.The resulting product is a pixel level probability of success (%) in the classification according to the logistic regression model (this is to say predicted probability; id="LC_Prob" coverageDescription). Note that for validation purposes, a threshold of 50% in this layer values is set to define success in the classification (above 50%) or failure in the classification (below or equal to 50%). Besides, in the SPSS software the ROC test is done (SPSS applies this same success/failure threshold for this test). The result of the ROC test states the percentage of times the model is correct other than chance (if a value above 50% is obtained, this means the correct classification is not a result of a chance success). Other statistics obtained in the ROC test are sensitivity and specificity. In our case, the ROC value is 74%. The ROC value matches the global accuracy obtained in the confusion matrix.

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: This layer is the error model validation layer, i.e. a binomial layer representing coincidence between the values predicted by the logistic regression model and the observed values (either correct/incorrect pixels).

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: A selection in the LC_prob_source (is the same layer than LC_prob ID coverageDescription) layer applying the success/failure threshold to respectively above or equal 50% values and below 50% values generates a binomial layer of correctly classified/incorrectly classified pixels (this is to say predicted correct/incorrect pixels by the logistic regression model).

The hybrid classification product (id="LC_source") is crossed with the third subsample of the ground truth (25% of the MCSC: validation areas, named test-test) in order to derive another layer with coinciding categories between the validation areas (ground truth) and the assigned categories in the classification product (landcover map). A reclassified binomial layers assigns value 1 to pixels in which the category coincides (correctly classified pixels) and 0 to pixels in which the category does not coincide (incorrectly classified pixels). This layer represents observed correct/incorrect pixels.

The binomial layer obtained (predicted correct/incorrect pixels according to the logistic regression model) is crossed with the observed correct/incorrect pixels layer. In the resulting layer, the focus is on coincidence between predicted by the logistic regression model and observed either correct/incorrect pixels (this means that both combinations are fine: 1-1 and 0-0 in this overlaying). This layer is the validation layer. (1 999 080 number of pixels 1-1 coincident/424 893 number of pixels 0-0 coincidences, and 0-1/1-0 disagreements!. Taking into account that this validation is carried out in the 25% of the surface of the ground truth area -only where the validation subsample is available i.e. total of 2 848 866 pixels, in the end this implies a 85.08% coincidence -either in correct or incorrect pixels-)

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: Average success probability for the statistical cluster obtained from linear regression model (object level mean average success probability expressed in %)

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: The IsoMM (Isodata product) is the layer from which the polygons are delimited (polygons=statistical cluster). Polygons where grouped using ciclar application of MiraMon software. The variables are obtained from the weighed by area average values of the pixels contained in these polygons. The independent variables layers are F, F2, F3, R, R2, R3, H, I, P, Q and the dependent layer (for the testing areas subsample of the MCSC boundaries of the IsoMM -Isodata product-): this is to say mean of the probability of success % obtained at pixel level based on observed values for the test subsample).

Linear regression model fitting in SPSS software: selection of the best model based on higher adjusted determination coeficient and parsimony principle. The selected model only uses F as independent variable (Adjusted determination coeficient=0.943)

Validation of the linear regression model by replicating the process using as dependent variable the mean probability of success in the validation subsample (this is to say, the 25% test_test areas: MCSC_test_test_12cat). The obtained goodness of fit statistic Adjusted determination coeficient values is similar (0.931). Application of both models and correlation between predicted mean probability of successes (%) between both models' predictions: very similar models, and very close to 1 correlations.
Application of the Linear regression model in the algebra calculator in MiraMon software: generation of the mean probability of success at polygon level.

gmd19157:statement.gco:CharacterString: The obtention of the hybrid classification product (ID="LC" in coverageDescription) is explained on the next processStep (id="IsoMM_process"). Moreover, see the reports explaing the traces: ConfMat_test_trace, RegLog_trace, RegLin_trace for other coverageDescription's lineage.

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Unsupervised classification (Isodata algorithm) of 47 standardized bands (6dates x6bands=36 landsat bands, 1 slope map, 6 NDVIs, 4 topoclimatic variables)

Landsat-5 Thematic Mapper (path 197, row 31) 6 dates multitemporal set (2005-2007), 6 optical bands (30 m spatial resolution). thermal band discarded due to low spatial resolution (120m) after geometric correctected

Geometric (Palà and Pons 1995) and radiometric corrections (Pons and Solé-Sugrañes 1994) using ASTER DEM (ERSDAC 2009), applying clouds, cloud shadows, sea and snow cover masks. Resampling to 20 m spatial resolution.Transformation to calculate NDVI (Spectral vegetation index -Rouse et al. 1973-) for each date. Bands standardization (Spiegel 1991) to avoid difference of measurement units among the bands to be introduced in the classification process.

Slope map derived from DTM based on PNOA at 5 m spatial resolution using 8 neighbours method and adapted to the 20 m resampled bands (median resolution change). This band is intended to account for the relief in terraces, abrupt or vertical slopes. Standardization of the slope maps to avoid difference of measurement units among the bands to be introduced in the classification process.

Topoclimatic variables calculated from the historical series of the Digital Climatic Atlas of Catalonia (minimum temperature of the average minimum temperature of the three coldest months, maximum temperature of the average maximum temperature of the three hotest months, minimum limiting precipitation of the three months with less precipitation, minimum solar radiation of the three months with less solar radiation). Standardization.
IsoMM process result in 957 statistical clusters
Supervised classification introducing the training areas (subsample of the 50% of the MCSC: MCSC_train_12cat). Fidelity and representatitvity parameters set to 0.

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Legend choice is subjective. Some of the original 233 categories have been reclassified as nodata. In the end the % of the MCSC that has been used (with buffering) is 41.38% of the study area. Difficulties in fitting the photointerpretation product legend with a suitable spectral features legend.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: Use of the Habitats Maps of Catalonia -available online from the regional government web- to compare the categories between them and reject the most mixed ones when doubtful.

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: The classification steps (both unsupervised and supervised classification steps) are affected by the selection of the multitemporal landsat scenes. In order to avoid shadows to minimize radiometric corrections loss of pixels, we have not selected scenes from November to March, and the avoidance of this period is crucial in the correct classification or distinction of broadleaved tree species and other categories. Nonetheless, the main problem in classification in Mediterranean areas is the diversity and presence of mixed forests and landcovers.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: Include autumn-winter scenes in the classification to better discriminate coniferous/deciduous species, but the most problematic is to distinguish within deciduous species (other scenes during the spring-summer period should be included, when some species have already grown leaves whether others have not yet).Consider NDVI discrimination criteria between the most problematic categories is not useful in this case because most forest landcovers are mixed forests and eventhough the broadleaved loose their leaves, other holm oaks are underneath and introduce confusion in the hybrid classification process.

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Some methodological constraints can be defined.

gvq:workAround.gco:CharacterString: First of all be careful with legend categories (legend is always a subjective choice). The legend chosen is suited to the objectives of the present study. However, it might be unsufficient for precise ecological or botanical studies at local scales. Classification methods differ in results at pixel level, both in categories assignment and associated uncertainty. Moreover, be careful with areas with high uncertainty (checking them in the provided probabilistic maps). Spatial and temporal resolution constraint the potential usage of the product).
